subject: Support trusted boot using iPXE
commit_message:
Support trusted boot using iPXE

With this patch, Ironic can boot nodes with trusted
boot using iPXE.

As iPXE didn't support multiple loading,
which is necessary to trusted boot. So trusted boot using
iPXE is actually regress to reuse PXE to deliver kernel and ramdisk.

The work flow is like this:
1. Ironic generates a special ipxe script file for nodes which
enable trusted boot.
2. These nodes boot into trusted_boot.ipxe and load pxelinux.0.
3. pxelinux.0 will directly fetch corresponding pxe config
   and load kernel and ramdisk.

It is recommended to enable trusted boot using PXE, but
if users are already using iPXE, it is still possible to
enable trusted boot for some nodes without change all to using PXE.

Implements blueprint bare-metal-trust-using-intel-txt

openstack_auth.backend: Error getting domain scoped token during login

Examining the Horizon Keystone driver, we see that on user login, it
will attempt to get both a domain scoped token and project scoped token.
A domain scoped token is needed since for Multi-domain deployments there
are RBAC domain-specific policy rules. However since ours is a single
domain deployment we ONLY exercise the project scoped token, and
therefore the project based RBAC rules.

There is however a bug here, where it shouldn't even be trying to get a
domain scoped token if multi-domain has been disabled in Horizon
(OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT in local_settings)

Since this option is disabled, there is no way to assign a role for this
logon user on any domain so domain scoped token calls will always fail,
not to mention being a totally redundant call out to Keystone.

subject: Adopt python-openstacksdk into shade project
commit_message:
Adopt python-openstacksdk into shade project

While shade has been focused on a high-level python interface to
OpenStack that hides vendor differences, python-openstacksdk has been
focused on exposing the REST APIs as they are in python. The two tasks
share enough underpinnings that having two separate teams work on two
separate efforts is not an efficient use of resources these days.

python-openstacksdk by nature of its name sounds to people like it's an
official project but has never been made one which causes confusion.

As a result of shade and openstacksdk having been parallel efforts and
the different teams having slightly divergent points of view on how to
structure abstractions, openstacksdk is sadly unusable by shade in its
current form. Such divergence at this point doesn't improve the world for
anyone.

Bring the python-openstacksdk repo officially into the shade project.
The intent will be to evolve both projects into sharing a holistic
approach to consuming OpenStack APIs with openstacksdk as the lower
level and shade as a business-logic layer on top of it. This will mean
an amount of breaking changes to openstacksdk, although as it has not
yet released a 1.0 that is less bad than it otherwise could be. As
python-openstackclient uses python-openstacksdk for neutron
interactions, great care must be taken to not break
python-openstackclient in the process.

The existing shade-core will be merged with members of the
python-openstacksdk-core team who desire to continue.

Discussions of merging or consolidating repositories will follow at a
later date if they prove to be valuable but are not being proposed at
this time.

Change-Id: Ibc0e6200121a536dc7072af9049a68eac8bb28e9

subject: Add shared_targets and backend_name to volumes
commit_message:
Add shared_targets and backend_name to volumes

It would make life simpler for Nova and other consumers to know
if theyr'e dealing with devices that utilize shared targets and
give them explicit information to enable things like device
(backend) locking.

This change adds a new column to the Volume Table, shared_targets.
The shared_targets column is a boolean that indicates if the device
that hosts the volume utilizes shared_targets or not.  By default
we set this to True because it's safe to treat all volumes as shared
but not the other way around.

In addition we also transform the host column in the volumes table
and use it to add backend_name to the detailed volume response.  This
is done in the API and added as a new field in the V3 view builder
for the specified microversion.

The purpose of these two items is for Nova to easily and clearly
determine if it should utilize locking around attach/detach operations.
If shared_targets == True, then it's advisable to use locking, and the
backend_name string is a recommended lock name.

subject: Fix cluster group migration status checks
commit_message:
Fix cluster group migration status checks

We incorrectly assumed that the group state will immediately become
'Pending' when a migration is requested, judging by the expected
'ErrorPending' return code of the move function.

This is not the case, as the group can be reported as 'Online' while
being on the source node, before a live migration is actually
performed successfully. This is incorrectly treated as an exception
at the moment.

This change refactors the way in which we check pending migrations.
We rely on cluster group state change events in this matter.

In case of migration timeouts, we're now attempting to cancel pending
migrations.

Also, some of the private methods functionality is now publicly
exposed (e.g. canceling migrations, detecting queued migrations).

In the future, we're planning to implement a custom cluster resource
dll, having a finer control over this.

subject: Clean up ENV vars mistmatches in Dockerfiles
commit_message:
Clean up ENV vars mistmatches in Dockerfiles

Containerized deployment through DevStack had two bugs related to
mismatches in handling environment variables in Dockerfiles:

1. cni.Dockerfile was using ENV vars to define CNI bin and conf
directories, but when DevStack was building them it wasn't setting them
correctly. This resulted in CNI binaries and configs ending up
in wrong directories when deploying through DevStack. This is fixed by
passing $CNI_BIN_DIR and $CNI_CONF_DIR into the build function.
2. cni_builder script used $CNI_BIN_DIR_PATH, but it was only defined in
cni.Dockerfile and was is missing from cni_builder.Dockerfile. This
resulted in malformed kuryr-cni script, that pointed to non-existing
"/kuryr-cni-bin" file. This is fixed by adding those ENV vars to
cni_builder.Dockerfile

Closes-Bug: 1718137

subject: XenAPI: upport XenServer deployment.
commit_message:
XenAPI: upport XenServer deployment.

This contains the following chanages to support XenServer:

1. XenAPI is the virt type for XenServer, add XenAPI as the new option
for nova_compute_virt_type

2. Customize the service configuration for XenAPI

3. Create a new role for XenAPI:
In XenServer, there is a privileged domain which is known as dom0; and
it can run a number of un-privileged domains which is known as domU.
The OpenStack services run in domU. Some compute relative services
(e.g nova-compute, neutron-openvswitch-agent, ceilometer-compute) run
in a domU but need communicate with dom0 to performance some hyperviosr
operations: e.g. boot VMs; controler dom0' openvswitch; query metrics data.
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/admin/configuration/hypervisor-xen-api.html

These services use XenAPI to communicate with dom0 through the
host internal management network (HIMN). When preparing the VMs where
the OpenStack compute services will run on, we can use the XenCenter's
HIMN plugin to create this network and attach the VM to this network
from XenCenter - https://github.com/citrix-openstack/xencenter-himn-plugin.

So besides the common tasks, we need some additional tasks for XenAPI:
- detect the interface connected to HIMN in domU;
- install XAPI plugins to dom0;
- install packages to dom0;
- configure iptables to allow the traffic between dom0 and OpenStack endpoits.
- etc.

The above operations will be implemented via tools belong a separate package.
But we need a new role to hold these tasks which invoke those tools. This
commit created a new role named as nova-xenapi which will be applied at early
phase so that the needed preperation work completed before other common
deployment start.

4. Add a new neutron-openvswitch-agent service:
For XenServer, we need two instances of L2Agent (neutron-openvswitch-agent
service): one manage the OpenvSwitches in domU and the other manage the
OpenvSwitches located in dom0.
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/matelakat/shared/xs-q-v1/xenserver-quantum/deployment.png

So we propose to add a new neutron-openvswitch-agent-xenapi service which
manages the ovs in dom0 for XenServer, the new service will use the same
docker image as the existing one but the ml2 configure file need to be
customized so that it can manage the remote host properly.

Change-Id: I317e39d9b2f94d96de133103154042e2ada0f43f
blueprint: xenserver-support

Now when we are going to deprecate timeutils.set_time_override()
and use mock instead, it easy to hit the following gotcha: when
testr does tests discovering, it imports all modules within a given
directory and it might happen that common.db.sqlalchemy.models

subject: Cyborg Application For Official Projects
commit_message:
Cyborg Application For Official Projects

First of all thanks for TC audience for our project update at PTG.
The overview slide presented at the meeting could be found here[0].

**What is Cyborg**
Cyborg is a new project that aims to provide a general management
framework for accelerators[1], such as FPGA, GPU, ARM SoCs, NVMe
SSDs,DPDK/SPDK,eBPF/XDP and so forth, basically any types of dedicated
hardware/software that designed specifically to accelerate the
performance of the general computing infrastructure.

**Motivation**
The motivation behind Cyborg projects orginally came from NFV in Telco,
and later on more from Scientific WG on HPC and public cloud providers
who want to provide FPGA/GPU instances. Details of the requirement for
Cyborg could be found in the slide[0]

**Two Important Facts**
- Cyborg is started from scratch within the community, which means there
was no code dump from vendor and we wrote every specs and code implement-
ation from zero in an OpenStack way.
- Every decision in Cyborg project is done through election/voting, even
the project name was voted from team members.

**One More Fun Fact**
* We have the LONGEST team meeting in OpenStack (meeting starts late in
China timezone and often left open since the organizer passed out on desk,
we are working hard to improve on that :) )

**Functionality**
Cyborg's two main jobs are resource discovery and life cycle management,
which means Cyborg leaves the functionality of scheduling entirely to
Nova when the user needs a virtual machine deployment, or Kubernetes/Mesos
/Docker if the user needs container solution running on baremetal.

**Cross Projects Relationship**
As mentioned above, Cyborg interacts with Nova via Placement. Cyborg does
not reinvent any wheels or tries to drop in to replace any current modules.
It heavily relies on working with the current OpenStack structure. Nova's
FPGA/GPU support is very critical for Cyborg to be able to work for VM
related deployments.

In short, after cyborg-agent performed resource discovery operation via
various drivers it connects to, it reports the accelerator resource info
to Placement. Placement will then provide an aggregate view of both general
and accelerator resource for Nova scheduler. When Nova successfully spawn
an instance on a compute node with accelerator, nova will notify cyborg and
cyborg-api will notify cyborg-db to change the resource status from
"available" to "in use", similar to the Nova-Cinder interaction for volume.

Cyborg has constant discussion with the Nova/Placement team and
we will continue to do so in Queens and following cycles to make sure we got
an awesome collaboration.

Cyborg has also very good relationship with the Scientific WG and OPNFV
DPACC project. We gathered inputs/requirements from these groups.

**Scenario/Usage**
To put it very simply, if you have just one type of accelerator, you could
just use what Nova provides for PCI-passthrough functionalities. If you have
more than one types of accelerators, or you have one type of accelerator but
you want fine grained control, then you probably needs Cyborg on the side to
help you manage them, working alongside Nova.

**Community Principle Compliance**
Cyborg project follows the core principle of "Four Opens" within OpenStack
Community:

* Open Source
This goes without saying, all the Cyborg source code could be found at
OpenStack repo[2] or its github mirror[3], including feature codes,
documentations[4] and tests[5]. Apache Lisence 2.0 is applied as usual.

* Open Design
As mentioned above, Cyborg is designed from ground up within the community.
We have weekly team meetings[6] at #openstack-cyborg and public available/
searchable meeting logs[7]. We have organized PTG design sessions for each
of the past ones[8][9]. We have also used [acceleration] or [cyborg] for
mailinglist discussion.

* Open Community
Cyborg has a truely diverse team composition with no single vendor
dominance[10]. PTL of Cyborg comes from Huawei and current two core reviewers
come from RedHat and Lenovo. We have also gone through election/voting for
these positions[11][12].

* Open Development
All of the Cyborg pacthes could be found here[13]. We have a implicit policy
of the core that landed the patch should comes from a different company of the
ones that submit the patches. We try to review the patches as thorough as
possible and we are honored to have people from other team help reviewing,
for example[14][15]. Cyborg team also tries to utilize all the available
community infrastructure, e.g CI/CD[16]

The Cyborg project team has been doing everything according to the community's
tradition and best practices. Although it is far from perfect, we believe it is
on the right track. We also believe that by putting Cyborg under official
governance, it will show OpenStack's capability on heterogeneous computing that
provides the foundation for AI, Machine Learning, HPC, NFV and many other
cutting-edge technologies.

Remove Neutron agent management API tests

The Neutron community has been engaged in a long running
effort to move some of the networking API tests to the Neutron
tree. We started by copying the api/network directory tree,
later keeping only the tests, importing the test infrastructure

One issue that remains is that the tests are still duplicated.
Since the tests run against stable/{kilo|liberty|mitaka} and
master, it should be safe to dedup. The Neutron community drew
a line in the sand, where core resources remain to be tested
in Tempest and more 'advanced' APIs are tested in Neutron.
More detail may be found here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/neutron/devref/
development.environment.html#api-tests

I removed all API tests for 'core resources' from the Neutron
tree, I propose that we remove the inverse from Tempest.
The full list of tests that I propose be removed from Tempest
is tracked here:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-tempest-defork
Ctrl-F for 'Tests that should be deleted from Tempest'

I believe that as far as Tempest test removal criteria found at
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/QA/Tempest-test-removal
This case falls under the first exception:
'The class of testing has been decided to be outside the scope of tempest'
and we may skip the three prong rule for removal. Note that none of the
tests I'm proposing for removal are a part of refstack.

subject: Correct RBD Provision stats&fix a perf problem
commit_message:
Correct RBD Provision stats&fix a perf problem

Use v.size() to get virtual size of volumes for
provisioned_capacity_gb instead of v.diff_iterate().
There are two reasons:

1.The diff_iterate() API of librbd returns actually
allocated size of volumes, but cinder-scheduler just want
virtual size by v.size() for provisioned_capacity_gb to
compute the ratio of over subscription.

2.Traverse all the volumes with diff_iterate() brings
greater pressure to both cinder and ceph cluster. It
can cause critical problems:
a. Run a periodic task may need a long time(may be need
serval minutes), depend on how many volumes in backend
pool and the load of ceph cluster;
b. Periodic report of the service can be blocked, and
cause service down in the end.

Change-Id: If37e3820ebd00c85e11f1fbb1f32faabf0890bbb
Closes-Bug: #1649956
(cherry picked from commit b907450d7d7500fbcb9e4040efc2d0e42f4a78f9)

Currently, to_primitive tries to iterate through all addresses in the
network, because the type doesn't have a special handling that would
short curcuit it, but also has __iter__. This may be detrimental to
performance, up to the point of node crash due to memory exhaustion if
the passed network range is too large (think of 0.0.0.0/0 or even
2001::/64). This behavior also makes it impossible to restore the
original data format (CIDR).

This patch short curcuits the iteration by handling the IPNetwork type
as a special case, same as we do for IPAddress.

OS::HeatSoftwareDeploymentGroup (plural) resources from deploy-steps.yaml.

This patch adds support to the command to also pull the deployment
resources for each individual server from the OS::Heat::Value resources
called "TripleODeployment", as well as other SoftwareDeploymentGroup
resources not from deploy-steps.j2. See the Depends-On
tripleo-heat-templates patch for how these resources are mapped.

These deployments are applied by additional plays in the generated
playbooks. Instead of having to reimplement each deployment in a native
group:ansible, the ansible tasks just trigger the deployments by calling
55-heat-config remotely with the rendered json deployment data for
whatever deployment is being applied.

native ansible (and requring all end users to do so).

subject: docs: installation: remove unnecessary blockquotes
commit_message:
docs: installation: remove unnecessary blockquotes

Due to missing spaces, some of the content in the installation
guide is displayed as blockquote without being really quoted
content. This change adds the needed spaces to remove the
generated HTML blockquotes.

The repositories.txt file gets included at different locations
and that file contained the formatting spaces which were needed
from the location which includes that file. It's most of the time
better to do the indentation at the ".. include" level and leave
the file which gets included *without* indentation. Because here,
the indentation in the included file worked for some includes but
not for all, because the content got used at different indentation
levels. That made it necessary to touch the includes in
basic_deployment and post_deployment too.

Follow up patches will deal with the other install guide sections
more in details.
